Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Investigation and Redesign of Nonribosomal Peptide Synthetases

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit:
The project involves an investigation and redesign of biosynthetic pathways of known natural product biomolecules. The engineering of such pathways is currently one of the most promising routes toward the development and production of novel structurally diverse biologically active molecules. Efficient combinatorial biosynthesis critically depends on mechanistic information on enzymes involved in natural product formation. Incompletely understood, intriguing, and even unique enzymes are found in the gene cluster of the bisintercalator natural product thiocoraline. The project uses in vitro reconstitution of the thiocoraline biosynthetic pathway, predominantly through mutagenetic manipulation, mechanistic, and structural characterization of individual enzymes, in working towards (i) gaining the ability to manipulate the derivatization of the amino acid L-tryptophan for future production of novel bisintercalators and thiopeptide antibiotics, (ii) understanding the mechanism of stimulation of activity of adenylation domains (integral components of nonribosomal peptide synthetase assembly-lines) by MbtH-like proteins and the potential role of these enzymes in combinatorial biosynthesis, (iii) gaining insight into the function of interrupted adenylation domains, and (iv) developing novel adenylation domains with broad or altered substrate specificity to extend the ability to manipulate nonribosomal peptide synthetase assembly-lines for combinatorial synthesis. The research has the potential to advance the understanding of the mechanism of unique enzymatic transformations and is expected to contribute to the development of new tools for engineering of natural biosynthetic pathways.

Broader impacts:
Through the proposed activities of the project, students from local high schools surrounding the University of Michigan, as well as undergraduate and graduate students, will receive the hands-on experience of modern research in the fields of biochemistry and structural biology. Through the development of a freely accessible database on nonribosomal peptides, polyketides, and their hybrids, undergraduate and PharmD students will be introduced to research and will have the opportunity to raise their overall scientific literacy. Finally, through a high school outreach program, high school students will not only be introduced to modern and interdisciplinary science, but also will be well informed on and provided with guidance for planning a successful and rewarding scientific career. The goal is to establish an integrated educational and research program to develop future scientists interested in working at the interface of chemistry and biology and to spark and foster the interest of students in science at different stages of their education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The engineering of natural product biosynthetic pathways is a promising direction for the development and production of new structurally diverse biologically active compounds. However, the lack of mechanistic and structural information on many enzymes of complex biosynthetic pathways continues to hinder our ability to manipulate these machineries. To address this fundamental problem, we performed the following studies: (1) investigation of unique enzymes involved in the formation of the natural nonribosomal peptides thiocoraline, echinomycin, congocidine, and pyoluteorin; (2) biochemical and structural investigation of MbtH-like proteins in combination with cognate and non-cognate adenylation enzymes, (3) biochemical, structural, and engineering investigations of bifunctional adenylating/methylating enzymes, and (4) investigation of halogenating enzymes. In study #1, we established the correct pathway used by Nature for the formation of the 3-hydroxyquinaldic acid moieties of thiocoraline by investigating many of the enzymes involved in this process. We deciphered Nature’s clever and intricate way of N,S-dimethylating the amino acid L-cysteine. We also provided enzymatic evidence for a revised congocidine biosynthetic pathway. In study #2, we showed that MbtH-like proteins can be used with non-cognate adenylation domains to increase their substrate promiscuity. We determined the structure of an MbtH-like protein with its adenylation enzyme partner. In study #3, we determined how Nature utilizes bifunctional enzymes to perform adenylation and methylation of amino acids. We engineered novel bifunctional domains and demonstrated their dual activity. In study #4, we looked at two types of halogenating enzymes, those that halogenate small molecules and those that halogenate amino acid-like compounds tethered to a thiolation domain during nonribosomal peptide synthesis. We determined crystal structures of both types of halogenating enzymes.

 

Broader Impact: The broader impact aspect of this project is two-fold: (1) The scientific broader impact lies in the understanding and discovery/engineering of new enzymes for combinatorial biosynthesis. (2) This award also had a broader impact on the general public and the future generations of scientists. In addition to offering high school and undergraduate students the opportunity to work in the laboratory on the four studies described above, the major broader impact for this award was the creation of the SciCats “Science Cultivates Academically Talented Students” outreach program. With SciCats, PharmD and graduate students go to elementary and high schools to perform weekly science hands-on activities with students in line with the state curriculum. SciCats benefits all people involved in different ways. The elementary and high school students get to do hands-on activities that they would otherwise not have access to. The University students get to improve on their teaching skills and get the opportunities to engage with the public. SciCats is rapidly growing and will keep on impacting many generations of scientists.
